user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_create_response_from_buffer_copy:
```c
_MHD_EXTERN struct MHD_Response *
MHD_create_response_from_buffer_copy (size_t size,
                                      const void *buffer)
{
  struct MHD_Response *r;
  void *mhd_copy;

  if (0 == size)
    return MHD_create_response_from_buffer_with_free_callback_cls (0,
                                                                   NULL,
                                                                   NULL,
                                                                   NULL);
  if (NULL == buffer)
    return NULL;

  mhd_copy = malloc (size);
  if (NULL == mhd_copy)
    return NULL;
  memcpy (mhd_copy, buffer, size);

  r = MHD_create_response_from_buffer_with_free_callback_cls (size,
                                                              mhd_copy,
                                                              &free,
                                                              mhd_copy);
  if (NULL == r)
    free (mhd_copy);
  else
  {
    /* TODO: remove the next assignment, the buffer should not be modifiable */
    r->data_buffer_size = size;
  }

  return r;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
r = MHD_create_response_from_buffer_with_free_callback_cls (size,
                                                              mhd_copy,
                                                              &free,
                                                              mhd_copy);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 8.13 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No. The pointer mhd_copy is purposely non-const because it is passed both as the response buffer and as the context to the free callback (&free). free() requires a void * (non-const) so mhd_copy cannot be const-qualified without forcing a cast. Thus in this call the pointer cannot be const-qualified “whenever possible” and Rule 8.13 is not violated. (Note: if the function MHD_create_response_from_buffer_with_free_callback_cls itself exposed a non-const buffer parameter even though it never modifies the buffer, that function prototype would be the place to consider a Rule 8.13 violation — but the fragment shown is not a violation.)
